title-group.article-title: No Evidence for the Diagnostic Value of Borrelia Serology in Patients with Sudden Hearing Loss

abstract.p: In this evidence-based case report, we address the following clinical question: What is the predictive value of serological testing for Borrelia for diagnosing neuroborreliosis in patients with sudden sensorineural hearing loss? We searched for relevant articles in PubMed, Embase, and Web of Science. We retrieved 49 unique publications and screened the title and abstract of these articles for relevance. We included 2 of 12 studies initially considered relevant to answer our question. These 2 studies reported a seroprevalence of antibodies against Borrelia of 16% in patients with sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SHL) as compared with 13.5% in the general population, but in neither patients with definite neuroborreliosis were they found. To date, there is no evidence regarding the added value of routine diagnostic serologic testing for Borrelia in diagnosing neuroborreliosis in patients with sudden SHL. Neuroborreliosis seems to be a rare cause of sudden SHL, and routine screening of patients for borrelia antibodies in serum should therefore not be recommended.

sec.title: Clinical Case
sec.p: Two days ago, a 47-year-old woman woke up with hearing loss and tinnitus in her left ear. She is healthy and reports no incident preceding her complaints. On examination, her right ear is normal, while basic audiometry confirms left-sided sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SHL). In line with the guidelines for SHL of the Dutch association of ENT surgeons,1 you decide to prescribe her a short course of high-dose oral corticosteroid therapy. In addition, you consider ordering tests for further evaluation of the presence of treatable or dangerous conditions underlying her SHL, such as magnetic resonance imaging and a number of blood tests. While the Dutch ENT guidelines1 recommend diagnostic testing for Borrelia in patients with sudden SHL, the Dutch guideline on Lyme disease suggests that when a patient with sudden SHL has not been bitten by a tick, the presence of Borrelia is unlikely.2

In the literature, sudden SHL has been associated with Borrelia infection.3 This tick-borne spirochete has been shown to cause Lyme disease, for which treatment with antibiotics is indicated. As the European species of the Borrelia spirochete is more strongly associated with neurological symptoms than the predominant species in the United States,4 testing for Borrelia burgdorferi in patients with sudden SHL has not been considered during the development of the US guideline on sudden SHL, which will be published in 2012 (R. M. Rosenfeld, personal communication).

While the patient does not remember a tick bite, you consider serological testing to rule out the presence of Borrelia. But before you settle on ordering such a test, you decide to look for the evidence on the predictive value of serological testing for diagnosing neuroborreliosis in patients sudden SHL.

sec.title: Searching for Evidence
sec.p: We formulated the following clinical question: what is the predictive value of serological testing for Borrelia in detecting or ruling out neuroborreliosis in patients with sudden SHL?

We designed a search filter using relevant synonyms for the domain, which is patients with SHL, and the determinant, which is Borrelia serology (Table 1). We retrieved relevant publications in Embase, PubMed, and Web of Science using search terms in the title and abstract fields. A related articles search in PubMed and cross-reference checking was used to retrieve relevant missed articles and identify additional useful search terms. A total of 49 unique records were retrieved (Figure 1). All titles and abstracts were screened by R.B. and M.C.J.A. Studies were excluded if they were reviews, animal studies, or case reports; described only children; or were not written in English, Dutch, German, or French (Figure 1). Studies were selected when the following inclusion criteria were met: patients suffering from sudden SHL and serological testing for Borrelia with enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or Western blot, using cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) as reference test for the presence of neuroborreliosis. The criteria for relevance of the serologic tests and proof of neuroborreliosis in CSF were based on the European guidelines on Lyme disease.5 These guidelines state 3 criteria for diagnosing neuroborreliosis: (1) neurological symptoms suggestive of Lyme neuroborreliosis without other obvious reasons, (2) CSF pleiocytosis, and (3) intrathecal production of antibodies against Borrelia (which can be determined with an index of antibody titers in serum and CSF). When all 3 criteria are fulfilled, a patient is diagnosed with definite neuroborreliosis, and when 2 criteria are fulfilled, a patient is diagnosed with possible neuroborreliosis.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 49 unique records were retrieved, of which 12 articles were considered potentially relevant after screening titles and abstracts (Figure 1).6-17 After applying the selection criteria to their full text, 6 articles were eligible for risk-of-bias assessment (Table 2).

sec.p: For the 2 studies that were considered valid, the data could be extracted for answering our clinical question (Table 3). Both of these 2 remaining studies were performed in large hospitals in the south of Sweden. They tested sera for Borrelia-directed antibodies with commercial ELISA kits from the same manufacturer, while all CSF samples were tested for protein content, cell count, and Borrelia-directed antibodies.

sec.p: Hydén et al11 included 62 adult patients with sudden SHL in a 10-year period. Blood and CSF samples were taken on admission. Seven patients (12%) had either IgG or IgM antibodies against Borrelia in their serum. CSF testing as reference for diagnosing neuroborreliosis showed no abnormalities in the seropositive patients. Since no intrathecal antibodies against Borrelia were found in the seronegative patients, neuroborreliosis was ruled out in all patients.

Finizia et al9 performed a prospective study on 19 adult patients with sudden hearing loss. Six patients (32%) had IgG or IgM antibodies against Borrelia in their serum. Ten patients, of whom 4 were seropositive, had either or both elevated protein content and pleiocytosis in the CSF, suggesting some kind of pathology in the central nervous system. However, none of the patients had intrathecal antibodies against Borrelia, while other causes of CSF abnormalities were not reported. Therefore, the criteria for definite neuroborreliosis were not fulfilled in any of the patients. The prevalence of serum antibodies against Borrelia is very high in this patient group, compared with 13.5% reported in a study of the general population,18 which was cited by the authors.

The data from these 2 studies were pooled in a 2 × 2 table (Table 4), resulting in 81 patients with sudden SHL. Of these patients, 16% had positive serology for Borrelia, which is similar to the general population in the south of Sweden. The prevalence of neuroborreliosis in this patient group was 0%, as none of the patients was diagnosed with neuroborreliosis.

sec.title: Translating Evidence into Practice
sec.p: This article shows that there is no evidence to support the added value of serological testing for Borrelia for diagnosing neuroborreliosis in patients with sudden sensorineural hearing loss. Despite positive serology of 16%, the prevalence of neuroborreliosis in the available best studies is zero.

The major strength of this evidence-based case report is that we were able to study neuroborreliosis in both seropositive and seronegative patients, thus providing the ability to assess the specificity of ELISA for diagnosing neuroborreliosis.

Some aspects need further consideration. First, both studies were performed in the south of Sweden, where the prevalence of Borrelia-infected ticks is high. We have added the data of the 2 × 2 tables from the 2 studies. Still, the number of patients is relatively small. Compared with other countries, this may have resulted in an overestimation of the prevalence of positive serology.

Second, since antibody titers in serum and CSF take some time to develop, a patient infected with Borrelia may show negative results at the first presentation. Therefore, it has been recommended to test seronegative patients with symptoms suggestive of Lyme disease again after a few weeks. The patients in both studies were tested once. Therefore, the diagnosis may have been missed, leading to an underestimation of the prevalence of Borrelia-directed antibodies in both serum and CSF.

Third, if patients presenting with sudden SHL do not remember a tick bite or erythema migrans, this does neither rule out positive serology testing nor a diagnosis of neuroborreliosis. But in considering the diagnosis of neuroborreliosis, it should be noted that solitary loss of function in one nerve is very rare. In addition, our data suggest that routine screening for Borrelia-directed antibodies in these patients is not worthwhile.

Finally, if patients report a tick bite or other unexplained symptoms beside sudden SHL, neuroborreliosis should be considered and serological testing is justified. However, even with positive serology, neuroborreliosis is rarely reported in patients with sudden SHL.

sec.title: Answer to Our Patient
sec.p: We conclude that there is no evidence regarding the added value of routine diagnostic serologic testing for Borrelia in diagnosing neuroborreliosis in patients with sudden SHL. Moreover, the diagnostic value of determining Borrelia-directed antibodies for diagnosing (ie, ruling in or ruling out) neuroborreliosis in patients with sudden SHL has as yet not been demonstrated in valid clinical scientific studies.
Therefore, we consider it very unlikely that routine diagnostic serologic testing for Borrelia has additive value in diagnosing neuroborreliosis in patients with sudden SHL.

We informed our patient in the clinical case about our above conclusions. Because she remembers neither a tick bite nor erythema migrans, although other neurological symptoms have been ruled out, we refrained from testing her serum for antibodies against Borrelia.

We informed her that many patients with sudden SHL have some degree of recovery within a few weeks, even though a reason for the sudden hearing loss is rarely found, and there is considerable debate about the effectiveness of corticosteroid therapy. We planned a follow-up consultation a few weeks later to review her complaints and reassess her hearing.
